xxl.core.cursors.filters
Class Taker<E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.SecureDecoratorCursor<E>
      xxl.core.cursors.filters.Taker<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements returned by this iteration.
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>
Direct Known Subclasses:
KNearestNeighborQuery
public class Taker<E>
extends SecureDecoratorCursor<E>

A taker is a decorator-cursor that returns the next number elements of a given iteration. The number of elements that should be delivered from the given iteration is defined by the user as well as the input iteration the elements should be taken from.

Implementation details: The taker only contains further elements, i.e., its hasNext method returns true, if the underlying iteration has more elements and the number of elements returned by the taker is lower than the given number. If next is called the next element in the iteration is returned and the number of elements to be delivered from the underlying input iteration is decremented.

Note: If the input iteration is given by an object of the class Iterator, i.e., it does not support the peek operation, it is internally wrapped to a cursor.

Example usage: 

   Taker<Integer> taker = new Taker<Integer>(new Enumerator(11), 5);
   
   taker.open();
   
   while (taker.hasNext())
       System.out.print(taker.next() +"; ");
   System.out.flush();
   
   taker.close();
This instance of a taker delivers the first five elements of the given enumerator which contains the elements 0,...,10. So the output that results after consuming the entire taker is: 
   0; 1; 2; 3; 4;

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor, SecureDecoratorCursor

Method Detail

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
                throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

This operation is implemented idempotent, i.e., consequent calls to hasNext do not have any effect.

In this case hasNext returns true if the underlying iteration has more elements and the number of elements returned by the taker is lower than the given number.

Specified by:
hasNext in interface java.util.Iterator<E>
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
hasNext in class SecureDecoratorCursor<E>
Returns:
true if the cursor has more elements.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the cursor is already closed when this method is called.

next

public E next()
       throws java.lang.IllegalStateException,
              java.util.NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

In this case the number of elements that still have to be returned is decremented.

Specified by:
next in interface java.util.Iterator<E>
Specified by:
next in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
next in class SecureDecoratorCursor<E>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the cursor is already closed when this method is called.
java.util.NoSuchElementException - if the iteration has no more elements.

reset

public void reset()
           throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the cursor to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again without constructing a new cursor (optional operation). The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying data structure, are still persistent.

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

In this case the input iteration has to be reset and the number of elements that have to be returned by this taker has to be set to its initial value.

Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
reset in class SecureDecoratorCursor<E>
Throws:
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the cursor.
